text: The last time we talked to you, you had mentioned that's just what you were finishing up. So I just wanted to ask a little bit more about it after I read them. I guess this is sort of a general question, but to concentrate, say, specifically on Kirin and Arafel, if I'm saying those correctly. Yeah, that's correct. Were they modeled on any particular analogs? No. No, not really. As far as I'm aware, I just came up with a nut of whole cloth. Okay, the bigger question, what I was really interested in was why is Celtic and Welsh mythology, say, so appropriate for fantasy? Well, I think partly because I, and probably many readers, hold our ancestry from this area. and when you grow up within a culture you grow up subconsciously with that culture's myths taught you many of them in the form of attitudes and the way you look at the world expectations and this sort of thing I think it's useful for someone to be in contact with the actual mythos of the culture from which he comes, because that way you can examine more thoroughly the origins and significance of the attitudes which you may hold. Okay, you did, though, use some standard figures from Celtic mythology, didn't you? Like the, oh, let's say the Grugai, the Puka, the Thishi, and so forth? Yes, they are figures out of Celtic, And Catholic folklore, yes. As a matter of fact, as far as I'm aware, all of the figures that I used do come from that well, as it were. Okay, you do a great deal to make fantasy characters real, not the usual cardboard stereotypes. I find this fairly rare in fantasy. And I wondered if it was a conscious effort on your part, or that's the way you normally would write. I treat a fantasy character the same way I treat any other character I handle. I think that, well, myself I'm very bored when I read a character who is an absolute stereotype. I suppose that there would be a way to write a stereotype in such a way that they become interesting, the one that I can think of outhand. And if T.H. White's handling is a character of Galahad, he does handle him as a stereotype, but he does it so artfully that you begin to understand that that's his problem. A creation which I somewhat admire, but in general, if a writer is not aware exactly exactly what commodity he's handling, have been the writers in a great deal of difficulty. And myself, I don't believe that any person I've ever met was average. And perhaps that attitude spills over into my writing. Okay, as far as I can tell, you've written two books on Eildwood so far. when you conceived of the idea of that series, the two books, did you conceive of it as one, two, or more books? No, actually I conceived of it as a short story. I got a chance to work with my brother, and the two of us together somewhat created Arafel. He did the visual and I did the story when we did the Don Grant book. And when it became a novel I started putting The Dreamstone together with Eldwood. And of course they're not long enough for a novel. And then I began realizing I was going to have to rewrite the whole thing. But by the time I'd done all the research that I finally felt that I needed, I had so much material left over that that's how there happened to be a second book, but that's all there will be, as far as I intend. Okay, to Merchanter's Luck for just a minute, I guess, which is a little before both of those books. Again, the emphasis on there, to me, anyhow, is on character, along with a very convincing hard science background. I imagine that was quite a bit easier to write than Dunbelow Station, wasn't it? Not quite. Actually, it was a book I started to write when I discovered I needed background for it. So Dunbelow Station happened. You'll very often find that the books would seem to flow the easiest and to be so simple. The stories were in them quite, you know, quite deceptively simple. really do so on the groundwork of a very, very large background. And that's precisely what happened there. The world that you've created, the universe you've created for those two books, Down Below Station and Merchander's Luck, is a very complete one. You've gone to a lot of trouble to set it up. I wondered if you had sort of, now that you have sort of a future history in hand, if you plan to go on with it. Well, they already have. Actually, The Faded Sun sits within it. It happens considerably in the future and in a somewhat different direction. The Chana books sit within it. They happen in the opposite direction from Pel, which is Pelsetti. and actually the only books that don't really fit into it are the fantasy ones. Okay, The Faded Sun Trilogy is one of my favorite series. I guess I hadn't gotten that connection. Actually, it's quite remote simply because it's so far away. But if you recall the infamous security organization, ALSEC his alliance. It was founded by Sidney Mallory and continually within the alliance you have two forces that swing back and forth. You have the forces of constitutional law as represented by Damon Constantine in Gumbelow Station. You have the forces of security in the military as represented by Mallory. you see a little bit of that in Merchander's Luck less of it in Down to the Station because of course it's an informative period although you certainly see more of Mallory and you'll see it again in a book called 40,000 in Gehenna which is, I guess, as of this September from Fantasia Press and in that one that's the period just after down below station in which what I call the alliance union period of dirty tricks when they formally signed a peace treaty that are out maneuvering for advantage and do some rather unwise things it's a period of cold war Okay, yeah. Just one more brief question on the world down below station and Merchander's Luck. Do you plan any more works within that exact same period? Well, yes, there may be. I haven't decided. I'm going to write some more of what I call Merchander's stories. I think that the figure of the trader, the person of commerce after all what we're going out into space for has been sadly neglected in science fiction you know, any fiction is conflict and one of the easiest conflicts of all to generate is military and perhaps in our enthusiasm for writing exciting plots. We go overboard with battles and a feeling, you know, that tomorrow and the future are going to be populated by people with way guns and warships, this sort of thing. And one of the things I've been trying to bring forward is that though perhaps these things will exist in the long run it's the merchants that are the real heroes the ones that ultimately make civilization work and in some of the stories that I want to write within this universe it's going to be a conflict indeed that it'll be a different sort of conflict a conflict of men against hazards people against adversities of various sorts that are sort of like the tales of the merchant marine instead of the military Okay, on the last interview we got listening to it the other day, we did get a bunch on Merchander's Luck, even though I hadn't read the book at the time, so that's probably enough on that particular area. One I just thought of, let me stick an extra question in here, I'm getting down to the end. Are you moving towards some goal or some vision at the end of this future history, at the end of the civilizations you're setting up? Well, it's quite a large thing. I have a book of my own, which I doubt the world will ever see, which is merely a list of dates that coordinates the whole thing. And in a way, I'm telling the story of two superpowers, which begin in about the year 2350 and continue thousands of years into the future in various incarnations. The shockwaves sort of continue through the centuries. and one of the points is that there are various times the heroes or the villains some of my stories take place from the union point of view some of them from alliance there are times at which alliance becomes exceedingly repressive other points at which it is clearly the hero in the story there are times in which Union becomes a very unpleasant place, in which to live in other times at which it affords more freedom than the Alliance does. So it's more a very long-term story of the life and conduct of states as characters. But it will never appear in a single book because the story is so strung out over so many different periods and so many different aspects. It's rather like telling, say, the history of Europe and the history of Asia or whatever. They eventually grow too large even to call them nations. Okay, in other words, then you don't have any vision of a future universal Armageddon or some evolutionary spot the human race is moving toward that would, you know, some big culmination of these things? Well, in a way, the little theme that you saw toward the end of the Faded Sun is a very important marker in this period. No, I don't see a universal Armageddon. I think we've got more sense than that. We've at least demonstrated it thus far. I think that there will be a time of course one great change happens within Down Bay Station it's when however unwillingly Earth has to realize that mankind is not terrestrial anymore there's another important point somewhat further on when mankind begins to revise its ancestral ideas about property and place and territoriality beginning to adapt to space as a lifestyle and a way of thinking you see what they've done at the beginning they've carried the idea of nationhood and boundaries into space in an environment where it patently doesn't make enough sense. And their contact with the marine is somewhat important in forming a part of what becomes a vastly changed outlook on the universe as a whole. Okay, that book 40,000 of Gehenna, you said that's between the down-below station world and the Fated Sun trilogy somewhere in between those two? Oh, yes, yes. It fits actually in between the sequences down below Station, Merchanger's Luck, which sort of overlaps. Then Serpent's Reach, and then The Fated Sun, give or take a thousand years or so in intervals. But Gehenna fits in between Down below Station and Serpent's Reach. It's a period where Union has decided to cut Alliance off. Alliance only has one world, and they're really determined to nip that in the bud before they are able to expand to anything else. And there is territorially adjacent to hell, There's a little stretch of planeted stars, and Union knows it hasn't got enough resources to go in there and take them and develop the planets. So it decides that it will last them up so that they become untenable. And they do that by dropping 30-odd thousand people on each world without ecological preparation, without anything. They're expendables. And the idea being that if the colonies take, there will always be a problem for alliance because they're union-idoctrinated. If they fail, they will create such ecological disaster that alliance would never be able to use the place anyway. Okay, thank you. Okay, I have two more. One of them involves your... You've answered this a little bit as you've gone along, some of your future plans. I guess two things. I would ask sort of a general question about I assume you'll be writing both fantasy and science fiction in the future. And secondly, are you planning any more short story collections? Well, I... Okay, short story collections. not as such if one happens it will happen I suppose that well I just don't write many short stories most of the short stories I've written have been for directly for anthologies and some of them are going to be the sort of thing that's more or less confined to a particular anthology such as The Thiefs World which I do largely for fun. The question whether I shall continue to write fantasy, I have, I find, I used to write a great deal more of it than I do now. And the proportion that I write now is probably the amount that I will continue to write. Not very much, but some. Okay. Okay, I really have one more question. This is sort of a strange one. I hope you don't take it the wrong way, but I believe I've read everything that you've published. Maybe you missed a few short stories, but in my opinion, you are getting better. Now, that's not saying early science fiction isn't good, because it is. Well, one always hopes it wouldn't be better. Well, I was going to ask, are you conscious of yourself getting better? I'm conscious that that things get easier to do perhaps my touch is a little shorter it's sort of like riding a horse I've done it a long time you don't fall off as much I can conceive of stories now without any doubt that I can write them I used to go much more to the seat of my pants than I do. I think I'm much more in control of my medium than I was at the beginning. My goodness who isn't. After you've written a dozen books or so, you get to the point where you've already discovered how to achieve a certain number of effects, and I hope that I will continue to challenge myself with things that are harder to do. I think that one of the things that I've enjoyed very much is working with a publisher who does not attempt to hold me to one type of literature. I can write anything I want to write. and I find that that's artistically stimulating I don't if I conceive of doing a story I don't have to go before a committee and sell it I don't have to promise that I'm going to do it I just do it in the confidence that it will work and that it will be thought and that that to me is a very precious kind of artistic freedom. So I hope, indeed, I am getting better. I plan to go on getting better. I don't plan to sit still at a particular level. I will continue to experiment with the medium, doing occasional strange things and occasional traditional things as the mood takes me. Okay, this is more an observation rather than a question, But I would say the areas that I've been very impressed with and seen you get better in is one thing, is the depth and complexity of your characterization, but also a more, especially in these last three books, Merchandre's Luck and Dreamstone and the Tree of Swords and Jewels, is a, I guess, an economy where you can say so much more in fewer words. Well, that's very nice. Economy of expression is something that I'm quite fond of. I think that one of my earliest idols, oddly enough, is a very dead Roman by the name of Tubius Virgilius Morrow, who was, I think, one of the world's great masters at that. Man could say more in two words than most people could achieve in ten and hit you with the most unexpected turns in the middle of these sentences. And I always lamented as a student that one couldn't do that in English, and I did a lot of translating, and I did work at it a great deal, trying to achieve what he achieved in the English language coming out of Latin. Well, I think that it did have quite a bit of effect on my idea of what good style is. I've always felt that if one could write with economy in plain language so that you can be easily followed, that you use the words for maximum effect according to position, so that things occur to the reader more or less in the order in which they would occur to the person in that situation, that you have managed to achieve a great glow of immediacy by that effect. that you live producing instead of simply sitting in and being told about it. And indeed, that is something that I consciously try to achieve, is to tell the most what I can in the smallest amount of space. Okay, good. Gosh, there are a million things I think I'd asked, but then I remember that first interview and I already covered most of the other things I can think of, so I'll just let that do duty, you know, what I've asked before. Okay. So I guess the only thing I would say finally is do you, you know, as brief as this has been, I'm sure I've left out a lot. Is there anything you would like to say or get on, you know, to get in that interview that can have published? Currently I've got a piece coming out this spring called Voyager at Night. and I'm working right now on a sequel to The Pride of Chanor done not just because I have a major love of sequels but because I do a kind of a future history thing sometimes I haven't told quite all of a thing when I get through with an individual plot involving individual people so there's more to what happens in the contact than I had a chance to tell in Pride of Channer and there's some questions left unanswered and so all of a sudden the bug hit and I felt like doing a book which the Channer books to me are fun to do I enjoy doing them and for me they're kind of lighthearted and a chance to deal with a character who absolutely refuses doom and gloom. So that's been my project for quite a while and actually it got larger than I planned so it looks as if there are going to be two Turner sequels. As a matter of fact, I just started the second one. My goodness, I would imagine it's not going to be too long, and maybe somebody's already done this, is to do some kind of essay or timeline on your future history like I've seen for, say, Heinlein or Anderson or so forth. Well, some people have inquired about this sort of thing. The thing that I worry about is that my events currently take place a great distance apart. I know what the connecting logic is, as the creator, as long as I keep it sort of close to me, I can play games with it as I will. I'm a little nervous about having it set in concrete or print, as the case may be. But I have with, or at least, I can't even remember if I did it. But I thought at one time about including a little bit of chronology in appendices with some of my stories. I'm not even sure if I got around to doing that. But I may in future stories, which may give some people help at any rate. And I could see something like that happening eventually. Listen, where does Hunter of Worlds fit in? Well, Hundred Worlds is sort of one of those little things that happens off in a side pocket at a far future time. It sounds from the viewpoint of the local people very much as if all of humanity is involved. Actually, it's a little area of colonial expansion that didn't work out terribly well. and I have an idea where it's set, which is considerably out beyond where anybody has gotten to yet in my stories, but it's pretty well out on the fringes, I would say, probably. in the about halfway between Talsetti and Sirius up to about 40 odd light years plus okay good listen I said 10 minutes and I'm sorry I'm well over that now but I get fascinated talking about these things well listen as I told you in the letter um you know we're putting together it's going to be a series of hardback books from this press and uh you're going to be in the first volume and it this is the first book we've done and it's um we're going to have to update all the interviews we have to get the author's permissions the whole thing so it's probably going to be i would say a year at least before it's out oh sure why i always i always figure it's one year between doing it and getting it in the door Yeah, we will obviously send you a copy of it. Okay. And we sure appreciate the time you've given us. Alright, I wish you a lot of luck with it. Thank you, Ms. Cherry. We may be seeing a convention one of these days. Alright. Okay. Are you headed down to Fantasy Festival? When is that? This weekend, though. No, I'm afraid I can't. I teach here at the college, Odessa College. I'm an English teacher, and... They've got you, huh? Yeah, I've got a stack of papers to my office ceiling to grade, and we have two weeks after... Thanksgiving before Christmas starts, vacation, so my Christmas vacation is going to be my big vacation time, I'm going to California and probably visit some of the places out there but I don't know when the next convention I'll go get to is but anyhow good luck with your riding and I'm sure looking forward to it. Okay, thank you. Thank you. Bye. Bye-bye.

Okay, I really have one more question.
This is sort of a strange one.
I hope you don't take it the wrong way,
but I believe I've read everything that you've published.
Maybe you missed a few short stories,
but in my opinion, you are getting better.
Now, that's not saying early science fiction isn't good,
because it is.
Well, one always hopes it wouldn't be better.
Well, I was going to ask,
are you conscious of yourself getting better?
I'm conscious that
that things get easier to do
perhaps my touch is a little shorter
